title: Friday, 18th August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

It's difficult doing our daily frivolous stuff when the news flow turns so ugly

PM11:02am

But hats off to the Spanish cops for closing the stuff down in Cambrils so quickly

11:03 am
PM11:03am

I guess we should note what the un-American president had to say in the aftermath

PM11:03am

https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/898254409511129088

PM11:04am

That's a ref to bullets dipped in pigs blood. Something that didn't happen.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

I sense we are approaching the last days of the Trumpeter

BE11:05am

He's added ten years to the myth in less than 12 months though, which feels thematically accurate.

BE11:05am

Each Trump month is a year in human time.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Shall we try and crack on with this market?

PM11:06am

It's a bit Tinhat

BE11:07am

Yep .... I tried to set out the ML approach to tragedy earlier in the year ... https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-05-23/

11:06 am
BE11:07am

..... which leaves us with the selloff.

BE11:07am

A selloff that was gathering pace even before news broke in Spain.

BE11:08am

S&P down 1.5% overnight, 2nd worst day of the year so far.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

In part on speculation around Cohn growing a conscience and resigning.

BE11:09am

As Jim Reed of Deutsche recounts .....

BE11:09am

He is seen as the glue holding Trump's pro-business agenda together. The fears are that if he goes you take a further step back from tax cuts and deregulation. Notably the VIX moved from just over 12 to nearly 13.74 in 25mins as the news swept through the markets.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

.... denied, though, for what little that matters these days.

PM11:09am

Not quite sure how Cohn looks himself in the mirror. Similarly Schwarzman.

BE11:11am

I guess there's a Machiavellian logic to a lot that's Trumpistic .....

11:11 am
PM11:11am

(Seconded on VIce. I will try and find the link)

BE11:12am

See the latest from cartoonist weirdo overnight, for instance. Still on his seven-dimensional-chess thing, but now with added amorality.

PM11:12am

( https://news.vice....le-race-and-terror )

11:12 am
BE11:12am

(@Phil5: I don't know why people sell. I can only quote why they tell me they sell.)

BE11:13am

(Back to Jim Reid: "[T]ension continues to grow in US politics and may add to doubts on Trump’s pro-growth reforms. Republican senator Corker has told reporters that “..the president needs to….move away beyond himself…move to a place where daily he’s waking up thinking about what is best for the nation.” Further, another Republican senator Scott said “what we want to see from our president is clarity and moral authority.” Elsewhere, Trump was also busy himself, twitting “publicity seeking (Republican senator) Graham falsely stated that I said….such a disgusting lie.” and that Republican senator Flake is “toxic” and a “non-factor in the senate”.")

BE11:13am

The Trump bump seems very long ago now.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

But then, Scaramucci seems very long ago and I'm genuinely not sure when that was.

PM11:14am

Footsie off 76 points currently 7311.

BE11:14am

Last week? Last month? It's all just blurring together into a kind of hazy hellscape.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

In terms of movers, everything's down.

BE11:15am

Apart from gold and rats.

Randgold Resources Ltd (RRS:LSE): Last: 7,515, up 110 (+1.49%), High: 7,568, Low: 7,410, Volume: 261.67k
11:15 am
Rentokil Initial PLC (RTO:LSE): Last: 293.70, up 1.7 (+0.58%), High: 294.50, Low: 290.40, Volume: 1.59m
PM11:15am

hehe

BE11:16am

Downwards is a broad but quite shallow selloff, in which it's hard to pick specific features.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

I guess we could note Provident .....

Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 1,849, down 40 (-2.12%), High: 1,888, Low: 1,849, Volume: 156.11k
PM11:17am

Yeah, what's the story there?

11:16 am
PM11:17am

This started yesterday

BE11:17am

Well............. the short answer is that there isn't one ......

PM11:17am

Late morning

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The rather longer answer is that, if Provident were to put out a second profit warning due to the insourcing of its collection agent network, no one would be particularly surprised.

BE11:18am

You'll remember its first profit warning was based on the idea that the collection agents would be back up to speed pretty much instantly.

BE11:19am

Which looked ambitious, given the difficulty of winning back door-to-door credit customers if you stop visiting them for a few weeks.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Question two mostly relates to how bad trading has to get before the dividend is toast.

BE11:20am

Citi did some work on this halfway through yesterday.

BE11:21am

Management has been very keen to stress that the Board would be willing to look through short-term disruption to the business model when it came to assessing the final dividend for FY’17. For reference, the interim dividend was held constant vs. H1’16 at 43.2p. At the current share price, the implied dividend yield is 7.4%. If the company decided to hold it flat vs. FY’16a, the implied yield would be 7.0%.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

We believe that a dividend payout that is flat y-on-y is the worst scenario for investors based on the assumption that CCD profits go to zero (from ~£60m forecast). This equates to a ‘safe’ 7.0% yield, which should give the shares a greater degree of support than they appear to be getting currently, as judged by the share-price performance of late. It also makes it a more expensive ‘short’ for investors inclined to do so.

PM11:22am

Very clear risk at 7%

PM11:22am

I'd say

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Question is, assuming the market's right and door-to-door is pregnant with another warning, is "we'll keep paying an uncovered divi" the right thing to say?

BE11:23am

Or would that money be better used trying to fix the agent network that's clearly gone wrong since they moved off the freelance model?

BE11:24am

We could also go into the reasons why Provident felt it had to move off the freelance model, meaning fewer agents higher costs and massive transitional disruption .... but perhaps that's not for today.

11:24 am
undefined
BE11:25am

Anything much in terms of news?

BE11:25am

Oh!

11:25 am
BE11:25am

TAKEOVER OFFER OF BAIN CAPITAL, CINVEN FOR STADA SUCCESSFUL

BE11:26am

BAIN, CINVEN ARE SAID TO HAVE CLEARED THRESHOLD FOR STADA BID

BE11:26am

Wasn't looking promising this time yesterday.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

40-something acceptance.

BE11:27am

So .... I guess those involved deserve some congratulations in not blowing up the same deal twice, as looked quite likely earlier in the week.

PM11:27am

That would have been quite a feat

11:28 am
BE11:28am

While on drugs ......... so to speak .................

BE11:28am

........there's the AstraZeneca Lynparza news.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,424, down 57.5 (-1.28%), High: 4,481, Low: 4,422, Volume: 644.36k
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Lynparza approved with broad label for 2L ovarian cancer Maintenance. Doing nothing for the price, of course, even though it's unqualified good news.

BE11:29am

Come to think of it, why are we calling it Lynparza?

BE11:30am

That's the trade name.It's called olaparib. It's olaparib. We shouldn't use trade names for drugs.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Quick summary from Leerink, not for a general audience I suspect.

BE11:31am

This afternoon, the FDA approved the tablet formulation
of AZN’s (MP) Lynparza (olaparib; PARP inhibitor) with a broad label, regardless of gBRCA status, for “the maintenance treatment of adult patients with recurrent epithelial ovarian, fallopian tube or primary peritoneal cancer, who are in a complete or partial response to platinumbased chemotherapy.” The drug received the label despite only being tested in gBRCA patients in its Phase 3 SOLO-2 trial, with the agency relying on data from the randomized Phase 2 Study 19 trial (with the capsule formulation) in non-gBRCA patients. Both TSRO (MP) and CLVS (OP) are trading down on this news, given that both had tested their PARP inhibitors, Zejula (niraparib) and Rubraca (rucaparib) respectively, in all comers in their Phase 3 trials. But given the recent weakness in these stocks we think the Lynparza labeling decision may be a clearing event. As outlined in our previously notes (LINK, LINK) (CLVS initiation) we now expect a roughly even split between the three PARP inhibitors in the second-line or greater (2L) ovarian cancer maintenance setting

BE11:31am

Ha, yes. So. That's Clovis (rucaparib) and Tesaro (niraparib), who've been jittery around olaparib labelling.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

It's a three horse race in the indication, which is what keeps AZN's pricing for olaparib down to a mere $14K per month.

PM11:33am

And rather cheaper in the UK

PM11:33am

Saw something about Nice demanding a price cut -- to below £4k a month

11:33 am
PM11:33am

But Bryce -- why are you so against using trade names? They are generally easier on the tongue

PM11:34am

And sometimes easier to spell

PM11:34am

As well

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Because they're trade names. It's paracetamol, not Tylenol.

PM11:35am

Omg smile

BE11:35am

A lot of drug pricing power post patent expiries is on consumer fear and ignorance.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Paracetamol is a quite difficult word to say, yet we say it.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:35am

On pricing power

11:35 am
BE11:36am

The same rules should be applied for all drugs. Pharmaceutical companies are rentiers of the chemistry, not owners.

undefined
BE11:36am

Sticking with drugs, since there seems to be demand .....

11:37 am
Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 3,782, down 89.5 (-2.31%), High: 3,843, Low: 3,774, Volume: 769.82k
BE11:38am

Concerns are as detailed in the past. Haemo competition, ADHD spinoff destroying rather than adding value, pricing pressure on Branded across the board .....

BE11:39am

That's in spite of a couple of buyers being around. Evercore yesterday, which was an initiation, and also Exane BNP.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Roche’s ACE910 P3 data was well received by physicians at ISTH last month and we detected real
excitement in the possibility for broader use, if HAVEN 3 data is positive (data due YE17). Shortly
thereafter, CSL launched Haegarda at a competitive price point. We now adopt a more bearish
outlook for the non-inhibitor haemophilia (-8% pa 2017-22E) and HAE franchises (-7% 2018E),
resulting in a 15-20% cut to our 2018-22 EPS forecasts. Exane EPS estimates are now 10% &
12% below cons. in 2018 and 2019, respectively. While some may view these cuts as excessive,
we believe this is a necessary exercise in order to reset market expectations and sentiment.

BE11:40am

Despite a significant cut to our forecasts, Shire remains the cheapest stock in our sector trading at
9.8x 2018 PE (37% discount to peers) and 10.2x 2018 EV/EBITA (20% discount to peers)

BE11:40am

We are realistic, sentiment headwinds will persist until year end. The launch of CSL’s Haegarda
and HAVEN 3 data/US approval for Roche’s ACE910 are notable competitive catalysts. However,
negative outcomes from these events are more than reflected in the current share price, in which
haemophilia is effectively valued at zero. With the stock now below GBP40, and the ADR below
$150, we see an excellent entry point. Over the next 12 months we expect greater clarity on the
extent of the competitive threats, a decision on the future for Neuroscience, new drug approvals
(SHP643 US, Xiidra ex-US), continued strong FCF generation and debt pay down. We retain our
Outperform but lower our target price to GBP47.00 from GBP59.00 (offering 22% upside)

11:41 am
BE11:41am

(@fjp73: regulatory progress Indivior's made with the one-a-month formulation, where it does seem to have a demonstrable lead, seems to have eclipsed all other concerns. I'm not sure that's entirely sensible.)

BE11:42am

............ and as for Hikma

Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 1,129, down 60.72 (-5.10%), High: 1,188, Low: 1,125, Volume: 701.76k
11:42 am
BE11:42am

Day two slump post yesterday's three-part profit warning.

BE11:43am

Good note from HSBC that tears a strip off its Roxane acquisition.

PM11:43am

Do share

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Hikma has noted that pricing pressure − especially in generics − will likely continue for the rest of the year and into 2018, before stabilising or recovering. Management also repeatedly stated that pricing is cyclical, the industry has been here before and that it will recover. We disagree. The industry has never been in a position where drug pricing has come under pressure from increased competition and faster generic approvals at the FDA (both of which are cyclical) at the same time as drug price pressure has increased from Pharmacy Benefit Manager (PBM) consolidation (structural) and there has been a new alignment of PBMs, drug distributors and Pharmacies (also structural). Further, the McKesson-Walgreens and Express Scripts-Walmart Boots Alliance agreements that have aligned PBMs, drug distributors and pharmacies and which concentrate buying power even further, were only signed in May 2017, so their impact on drug pricing will not have been reflected in the H1 results for Pharma companies. This is one of the reasons that we think US drug pricing, including generic drug pricing, will likely remain under increasing pressure through H2 2017, into 2018 and beyond

PM11:44am

(You are welcome Risk_T )

BE11:45am

[T]here was potentially worse to come for Hikma in the US given its increased exposure to the US generic drug market after the Roxane acquisition. That view was not pessimistic enough; it is now clear that there is much worse to come. Further, the Roxane acquisition has not created value for the Group. Post the acquisition, the group’s ROIC has fallen from 24% in 2015 to our forecast 11% for 2017e.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

A reminder that a big part of Hikma's success is predatory pricing around shortages.

BE11:46am

And then it shifted into US generics at what could well be the top of the market for US generic pricing.

BE11:46am

Ahead of intensifying US generic drug price pressure, we cut our revenue forecasts by 6-9% pa over 2017e-2019e and EPS by 10-11% pa over the same period. We cut our DCF-driven target price from 1,410p to 1,060p; our rating remains Reduce

11:46 am
undefined
BE11:47am

Is there anything around other than drugs?

PM11:47am

Just looking at Merrill Wobble-ometer thing

11:47 am
BE11:47am

"Wobble-ometer"?

PM11:47am

Humpty-Dumpty starts to wobble

PM11:47am

This thing

11:47 am
PM11:47am

BE11:48am

............ I see. And this goes out to clients does it?

PM11:48am

They're saying get the hell out if/when this hits 8

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Obv written before latest events -- and before today's sell off

BE11:49am

So ......... today's selloff is a signal to buy?

PM11:49am

Talking Points
Risk-off flows: $1.3bn weekly outflow from equities, $3.5bn into bonds, $0.5bn into gold

HY & EM outflows cause Bull & Bear indicator to drop: biggest HY bond fund outflows in almost six months as spreads jump; first EM equity and debt outflows in almost six months coincide with bounce in oversold USD

Humpty-Dumpty: more imminent Aug/Sept risk-off trade plausible if poor politics shows up in consumer confidence, US dollar rises despite lower UST yields and further drop in US presidential approval ratings (dollar correlated with politics YTD - Chart 1); US high yield credit spreads gap toward 500bps; tech leadership reversal

11:49 am
BE11:49am

And when too many people buy you should sell?

BE11:49am

Wow, I wonder why a stockbroker that makes a commission on volume should adopt the advice of selling and buying when others are buying and selling?

BE11:49am

It truly is a mystery.

11:50 am
undefined
PM11:51am

Found some news

PM11:51am

PCG Entertainment -- fund raising

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Whatwhat what Entertainment? What are they?

PM11:51am

· Fundraising from institutional investors (the "Facility") arranged by RiverFort Global Capital ("RiverFort")

· Issue price under the Facility of 0.1 pence per new ordinary share

· The Facility (which comprises a subscription of £1.0 million and an equity sharing agreement) to be used to fund the Company's continuing operations, including general working capital requirements

PCG Entertainment Plc (PCGE:LSE): Last: 0.0898, up 0.0048 (+5.65%), Volume: 41.80m
11:52 am
PM11:52am

Raising money above the market price!

PM11:52am

Quite a feat for RiverFort Global Capital

BE11:52am

Ah, I see, one of those penny-to-two-decimal-places stocks.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Er, who are RiverFort Global Capital?

BE11:53am

Never heard of them. Nor PGC Entertainment, if I'm honest.

PM11:53am

http://riverfortcapital.com/

11:54 am
PM11:54am

That website (!)

PM11:54am

They manage not to name anyone involved with the firm

BE11:57am

Googling PGC Entertainment brings up page after page of Aim discussion boards and blogs focused on the .... um ............ less ...... sophisticated ......................... amateur ..................................... investment ............. community. You have to add a "PLC" to get their actual website.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

But I'm sure that's fine. Nothing to worry about.

undefined
BE11:58am

Hm ................ what else? I mean, everything's down so everything's down.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Oh! Interesting note from Codling at Jefferies on OTM.

BE11:58am

As in, On The Market. The estate agent portal that might be floating.

BE11:59am

And is giving free shares away to estate agents that sign up to use it.

11:59 am
PM11:59am

Is it still going?

BE11:59am

Apparently!

PM11:59am

Thought it had fizzzled almost immediately

11:59 am
BE12:00pm

They've ended the "two portal only" rule and are now looking to raise very little money, if I remember the story correctly.

BE12:00pm

Anthony Codling can explain.

BE12:00pm

The IPO will launch if 75% of those who vote, vote in favour of the IPO. Members who sign up to a new 5 year contract will be allocated shares. However, although all members have one vote, not all members will be given the same number of shares. We understand that there is quite a variance in the numbers of shares being offered, even in amongst the rank and file of smaller firms which make up the majority of OTM membership. If we were considering joining OTM we would be keen to understand how level the playing field was before we set foot upon it

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

The appeal of free shares, is no doubt strong; however, how
free are they? In order to receive the shares, agents sign up to a 5 year contract and single branch firms will have a 'base level' 5 year subscription cost of between £18,800 and £37,900 depending on location, bells and whistles will cost more. If a single branch is offered 12,000 shares the implied value is between £48,000 and £60,000, but the cost of these free shares ranges from £18,800 to £37,900.

BE12:01pm

The prize on offer may well comprise shares, but no shares may be sold during the first year of membership, only up to 10% of shares can be sold in year 2 and only up to 10% in year 3 with the balancing 80% having to be held for up to 5 years unless OTM provides written consent or a recommended offer for the company is made.

BE12:02pm

Which does seem an odd way to arrange things.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Why doesn't OTM offer free five year memberships to boost membership, and instead of giving away shares for free, sell them to investors? Jam today may be more appealing to new members than eggs in five year's time.

BE12:02pm

I imagine the answer to that is, "because they'd quite like £50m".

BE12:02pm

But then, £50m is nothing. Barely a few Tube billboards.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

A £50m raise equates broadly to Rightmove and ZPG's combined annual property portal advertising. We suspect that OTM will need to raise more money to fund its fight with the big two and this, in our view, will dilute the value of the shares currently being dangled in front of agents today. It is by no means certain that shares worth £60,000 at IPO will be worth £60,000 in five years time.

BE12:04pm

So, Rightmove continues to have what looks like an unassailable lead. Zoopla has done a reasonably good job of being the Pepsi of the sector, with added other stuff.

BE12:04pm

And OTM is ................... well, good luck to them I guess.

12:04 pm
Rightmove PLC (RMV:LSE): Last: 4,049, down 61 (-1.48%), High: 4,109, Low: 4,028, Volume: 73.27k
ZPG PLC (ZPG:LSE): Last: 350.10, down 4.9 (-1.38%), High: 354.40, Low: 348.50, Volume: 74.28k
undefined
12:04 pm
PM12:05pm

I think we are done.

PM12:05pm

Thanks for all that Bryce

PM12:05pm

And thank you, over on the right, for sticking with us.

12:05 pm
PM12:05pm

Back Monday

PM12:05pm

Bye

PM11:35am

Yes, I guess you are right there
